The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic has dramatically changed the educational landscape across the globe, forcing a shift from traditional in-person classrooms to virtual classrooms conducted online. This drastic change has ignited a debate on the relative merits and drawbacks of online learning. This essay will delve into the merits and pitfalls of online classes and will draw on personal experiences to support the argument. 

Commencing with the advantages, the principal benefit of online learning lies in its adaptability and flexibility. Not bound by a specific timetable, learners can access course materials anytime and anywhere, thereby catering to those who have work or familial obligations, or who dwell in remote areas. During a recent online marketing course I undertook, I was able to balance my everyday job with my studies, accessing course materials during the evenings or on weekends. I returned to the recorded live classes whenever I needed to clarify any doubts. Hence, it could be argued that online learning empowers a learner by providing the flexibility to learn at their pace in their personal space.

Furthermore, online courses offer a cost-effective solution for learners to acquire new skills. Aside from eliminating travel expenses, online courses often cost less than traditional classes. This lower financial burden empowers people from all walks of life to gain access to quality education. I vividly recall when one of my colleagues hailing from a economically-challenged background was able to pursue an online MBA course that otherwise would have been out of his financial reach. 

Lastly, online learning promotes a sense of self-discipline and responsibility through its learner-centered approach. The onus rests on the students to stay motivated and organized, qualities that not only augment academic success but also prove invaluable in career growth and personal life.

However, studying online is not devoid of its set of challenges. One prevalent issue critics often stress is the absence of face-to-face interaction inherent in traditional classrooms. The teacher-student rapport and peer interactions, both emotional and intellectual, are integral in creating an engaging learning atmosphere and fostering soft skills like communication and leadership. This aspect of in-person classes is generally diminished or absent in online classes. Personally, I remember my group project experiences during my undergraduate days, where brainstorming face-to-face with my team proved more effective than doing so online.

The digital divide is another formidable hurdle in the path of online learning. Not all students have access to stable internet, proper hardware, or the digital literacy required to navigate online learning platforms. For example, during one of my online classes, a fellow student, residing in a rural area, often struggled with consistent internet connectivity, leading to her missing important parts of the lecture.

Lastly, the effectiveness of online learning could be compromised by distraction and procrastination. With a myriad of distractions just a click away, staying focused can be more challenging for some learners. Remembering my own initial online learning experience, I often found myself drifting towards social networks or online games in the middle of a lecture, thereby disrupting my concentration.

In conclusion, as the move toward online learning becomes more pronounced, it is essential to understand its associated benefits and challenges. While online classes offer flexibility, cost-effectiveness and develop self-discipline, they also have their share of drawbacks like reduced social interaction, the digital divide and easy distraction. Therefore, the best learning approach may incorporate a hybrid system combining online and traditional methods, effectively leveraging the advantages of both. Such a blended learning environment might well be the future of education, providing an all-rounded educational experience that caters to diverse learner needs and preferences. It is crucial for educational institutions and policymakers to strive towards minimizing the disadvantages and maximizing the advantages, thereby making education more equitable, accessible, and efficient in the digital age.

This design was crafted to harmonize conflicting interests within the territories while offering checks and balances. However, one of its widely criticized drawbacks is that it negates the concept of 'one person, one vote', as the people indirectly elect the president. 

Secondly, the 'winner takes all' phenomenon is disconcerting as it disregards the votes of the losing candidate, leading to diminished representation. For instance, in blue states, votes for Republican candidates simply vanish and vice-versa for red states, thus not accurately reflecting the will of the people.

Amid this controversy, changing the Electoral College to a popular vote system seems appealing. Such a system could give voters a direct say in electing the president, enhancing democratic legitimacy. It recognizes every vote and fosters the nurturing of a truly national electorate.

However, it isn't flaw-free. It could lead to candidates focusing excessively on densely populated areas, leaving less-populous regions under-represented. It's also prone to fraud and manipulative tactics since individual votes would directly determine the leadership.

In conclusion, while the Electoral College system is not perfect, a shift to a popular vote system also comes with its challenges. Thorough deliberation is required to decide if maintaining the status-quo or adopting change serves the best interest of America's democratic principles. In the quest for a more holistic education system, summer projects have emerged as a crucial tool for learning reinforcement. However, the debate on the effectiveness of teacher-designed projects versus student-designed projects continues to plague the educational milieu. By considering facets such as engagement, challenge, time management, and overall success rates, we can draw a comparative analysis between the two paradigms.

On one hand, teacher-designed summer projects are characterized by structured assignments that are often tied to the curriculum. These projects are aimed at consolidating and applying classroom knowledge to practical scenarios, thus reinforcing learning outcomes. Teachers are experts at breaking down complex subjects into manageable portions, thus ensuring that projects are of an appropriate standard for the students' abilities. A study by Hattie (2008) found that teachers who designed the curriculum saw a substantial increase in student learning outcomes.

Furthermore, teacher-designed projects offer the comfort of a pre-defined roadmap. With the teacher monitoring progress, students can effectively manage their time and move through the project at a steady pace. This also reflects in the overall success rates, as seen in data from the Harrison School District; show a higher completion rate for teacher-designed projects.

Contrarily, student-designed projects promote a sense of ownership and independence among learners. This novelty fosters enthusiasm and engagement, a key component of effective learning. According to a study by Hanover Research (2015), students exhibited significantly higher motivation and engagement levels when they were involved in the project design process. 

Simultaneously fostering a rich environment for creativity and critical thinking skills, student-designed projects offer an intensity of challenge unlike any other. The forced application of knowledge carries the potential to deepen students' understanding and stretch their learning significantly. These projects follow a constructivist approach, positioning the student not as a passive recipient of givens but an active builder of knowledge.

Nevertheless, the transformative potential of student-designed projects is stifaced by the absence of time management skills, often resulting in incomplete assignments. A study by Zimmerman and Kitsantas (2014) found that younger students in particular may not have developed sufficient self-regulatory skills needed for successful design, planning, and execution of projects. This can dramatically lower the success rates linked to student-led assignments.

Having considered the benefits and challenges of both models, an optimal solution perhaps lies in a hybrid approach. A teacher-student collaborative structure infuses the best aspects of both paradigms, the structured guidance of the teacher, and the imagination and ownership of the student. Such a model provides students with a clear direction and criteria for success while still allowing imaginative freedom in terms of approach and execution. This intertwined approach was seen to greatly enhance student success and engagement in a study by Park (2013).

In conclusion, while teacher-designed projects ensure cognitive consistency, effective time management, and higher success rates, student-designed projects foster engagement, ownership, creativity, and enhanced challenge. Students may lack the discipline required to manage their time during autonomous projects, and without teacher supervision, they run the risk of deviating from the planned curriculum. Therefore, it is the amalgamation of both these paradigms in a teacher-student collaboration model that promises the best of both worlds: guided creativity, structured challenges, and assured completion.

In order to build an effective learning environment, it is incumbent on the teacher to evaluate their student demographics and adapt their project strategies accordingly. Understanding that a one-size-fits-all model will not suffice is a significant first step. Be it a teacher-led, student-led, or collaborative model, what matters most is that the chosen methodology caters to and enhances the unique learning capabilities of each student. Thus, in the journey towards academic excellence, we need to continuously reassess and tweak this delicate equation.

Title: Enhancing Student Engagement through the Facial Action Coding System

The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) is an intricate and comprehensive taxonomical structure designed to scrutinize the physical manifestation of emotions displayed through facial expressions. As Paul Ekman and Wallace Friesen, the forerunners of FACS, stated, facial expressions are signposts of our emotional states, often providing visual cues before we even articulate our feelings. In the realm of education, FACS has the capability to transform the learning dynamism by fostering improved student engagement and kindling their enthusiasm for classroom lessons.

Traditional teaching methods predominantly rely on communicating knowledge verbally without considering the feedback from students, beyond compulsory quizzes, exams or verbal responses. This model of instruction promotes a monolithic learning environment that fails to cater to vast and complex differences in how students process and respond to information. Consequently, this situation precipitates a lack of student engagement and diminished interest in classroom lessons. 

One way to address this issue is by employing meticulous observation of student facial expressions via FACS, intending to uncover the underlying emotions that prevail during the lessons. Being aware of students facial expressions and the emotions they represent has the capacity to foster a dynamic, responsive and personalized education system. When teachers discern student expressions of confusion, frustration, or boredom they could adjust their teaching methods accordingly. By alternatively focusing on the students exhibiting expressions of interest and understanding, educators can replicate the successful pedagogical tactics in future lessons.

Embracing the merits of FACS allows tutors to spot students who are disengaged or struggling immediately, providing an opportunity to alter the trajectory of the lesson and rekindle the learner's interest. Suppose students persistently display sentiments connected with confusion or disinterest. In that case, tutors can swiftly assess their approach, perhaps simplifying the content, integrating more exciting examples, or utilizing engaging teaching tools. With FACS, tutors can adapt the curriculum to fit the emotional learning landscape of their students more effectively.

Moreover, implementing FACS can support the identification and support of students dealing with emotional difficulties. Some learners might bewilderment and anxiety while learning but suppressed these feelings out of fear of judgment. Teachers, equipped with FACS knowledge, can detect these emotions and provide necessary emotional and educational support, thus creating an educational environment that addresses students' emotional wellbeing alongside their academic development.

The potential of FACS extends beyond teacher-student interactions. Students can also be trained to understand facial expressions better, enabling an environment that fosters emotional intelligence. Recognizing their peers' feelings might promote empathy and improved communication skills among students, creating a more harmonious classroom environment.

However, the effective implementation of FACS in classrooms necessitates comprehensive training. Teachers need to be educated on both the determination of intricate facial expressions and drawing accurate conclusions about student emotions. Moreover, implementing FACS should be done ethically and sensitively, for it involves delving into the personal emotional space of students. Therefore, proper guidelines should be set into place to protect students' privacy.

As classrooms shift from traditional didactic models to a more holistic, student-centered learning approach, implementing the Facial Action Coding System might be a powerful tool to foster a dynamic, responsive, and inclusive learning environment. With the potential to improve student engagement, personalize instruction, and support emotional understanding, FACS could revolutionize the way educators teach, students learn, and how classrooms operate.

These activities not only provide additional knowledge in various fields, but they also serve as one of the key components which colleges look for during the admissions process. Additionally, such activities often act as a positive outlet for those grappling with personal struggles.

As the President of the student council during my high school years, I learned to lead, multitask, and resolve conflicts – experiences that bolstered my college applications, contributing significantly to my acceptance into a prestigious university.

On a more personal level, extracurricular activities can also present a healthy channel for coping with personal troubles. For instance, during a challenging time in my life, I found solace in music. Regular rehearsals and performances provided a routine, an element of normalcy during a turbulent time.
